title: Effect of Rubisco and RAF on Photosynthesis

content.question: Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored. Increasing the efficiency of photosynthesis is one way to increase crop yield and help to feed human populations. One enzyme vital to the Calvin-Benson cycle of photosynthesis is Rubisco. Rubisco catalyzes the fixation of atmospheric <math alttext="C O 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> into organic molecules so that the carbon atoms can be used to produce carbohydrates. Rubisco is composed of two different types of polypeptide subunits: large subunits and small subunits. It is hypothesized that another protein called Rubisco assembly factor (<math alttext="R A F" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RAF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) is needed to help the polypeptide subunits fold together to form a functional enzyme. Researchers engineered three genetically modified strains of maize (corn). Strain <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> was modified to produce additional Rubisco polypeptides of both types in the cells. Strain <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> was modified to produce additional <math alttext="R A F" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RAF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein. Strain <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> was modified to produce both additional Rubisco polypeptides and additional <math alttext="R A F" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RAF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein. The Rubisco content of each of the maize strains studied is shown in Figure 1. Figure 1. Rubisco content in genetically modified and unmodified strains of maize. (<math alttext="minus" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>) indicates unmodified levels of Rubisco polypeptides and/or <math alttext="R A F" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RAF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein. (<math alttext="plus" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>) indicates additional Rubisco polypeptides and/or <math alttext="R A F" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RAF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein. The researchers then grew plants of each strain at a light intensity of <math alttext="500 micromoles of photons per square meter per second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>500</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">μ</mi><mtext>mol of photons</mtext><mo>⋅</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>m</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>⋅</mo><mtext></mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>s</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> and a temperature of <math alttext="25 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>25</mn><mo>°</mo><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. After <math alttext="40" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>40</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> days, the amount of Rubisco activity (as determined by the rate of carbon fixation) in each modified strain was determined (Figure 2). Figure 2. Rubisco activity (in <math alttext="micromoles of photons per square meter per second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">μ</mi><mtext>mol of photons</mtext><mo>⋅</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>m</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>⋅</mo><mtext></mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>s</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>) in genetically modified and unmodified strains of maize. (<math alttext="minus" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>) indicates unmodified levels of Rubisco polypeptides and/or <math alttext="R A F" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RAF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein. (<math alttext="plus" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>) indicates additional Rubisco polypeptides and/or <math alttext="R A F" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RAF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein. Researchers also evaluated several characteristics of the plants of each strain: the height, the fresh mass of the plants, and the mass of plants dehydrated in an oven (dry mass). The data are presented in Table 1. TABLE 1. AVERAGE PLANT HEIGHT, FRESH MASS, AND DRY MASS OF FOUR STRAINS OF MAIZE Strain Rubisco Production <math alttext="R A F" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RAF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> Describe the general structure of one of these monomers, including the characteristic that would allow it to interact with a hydrophobic monomer in a second Rubisco polypeptide.

overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>37.0</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>1.0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> (a) The small subunit of Rubisco is made up of many monomers. Describe the general structure of one of these monomers, including the characteristic that would allow it to interact with a hydrophobic monomer in a second Rubisco polypeptide.

(b) Identify the independent variable in the experiment whose data are shown in Figure 2. Identify a condition that was kept constant throughout the researchers' experiment whose data are shown in Figure 2. Based on the data in Table 1, describe the effect of additional <math alttext="R A F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RAF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> production and normal Rubisco production on the height of plants, indicating the strains you compare. Calculate the percent mass of the fresh plants in strain <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> that was due to water.

(c) Researchers engineer a strain of maize with a mutation that results in a decrease in the expression of <math alttext="R A F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RAF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Predict the most likely effect of this <math alttext="R A F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RAF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> mutation on carbohydrate production in plants grown under the same conditions as those of the experimental strains. Justify your prediction. In addition to binding <math alttext="C O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, Rubisco can bind <math alttext="O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Once Rubisco binds to <math alttext="O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, an energetically wasteful cycle called photorespiration must be completed before Rubisco can bind <math alttext="C O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> again. Predict the effect of an increase in atmospheric <math alttext="C O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> concentration on the likelihood that photorespiration will occur.

(d) A rare double mutation was found to be naturally occurring in switchgrass, a grass species related to maize. The mutations lead to the overexpression of both Rubisco polypeptides and <math alttext="R A F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RAF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Based on the information provided, explain how the fitness of the mutant switchgrass will compare with that of a mutant switchgrass overexpressing <math alttext="R A F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RAF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> alone. The small subunits of Rubisco are encoded by a nuclear gene while the large subunits of Rubisco are encoded by a chloroplast gene. A particular maize plant has a mutation in the allele encoding the large subunit of Rubisco. Pollen from this mutant plant is used in a cross with a plant that contains the normal allele. Explain why the offspring resulting from this cross will not express this mutation.
